title: KE of rock dropped from ferris wheel

content.description: An amusement park ride consists of a large vertical wheel of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that rotates counterclockwise on a horizontal axis through its center, as shown above. The cars on the wheel move at a constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the position of a car at the highest and lowest point of the ride, respectively. A person of weight <math alttext="F sub g" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> sits upright on a seat in one of the cars. As the seat passes point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the seat exerts a normal force with magnitude <math alttext="0.8 F sub g" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0.8</mn><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on the person. While passing point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the person releases a small rock of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which falls to the ground without hitting anything.
content.question: The kinetic energy of the rock when it is at the same height as point <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is most nearly
